Understates: The claim "a shortage is not expected" understates the potential for meat shortages due to the disruptions in the meat supply chain caused by COVID-19 outbreaks at meat-packing plants.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not acknowledging the clusters of COVID-19 cases linked to meat packing facilities and the concerns raised by experts about the critical condition of the meat sector.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides anecdotal evidence from a county executive and a spokeswoman, without presenting comprehensive data or expert analysis.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the meat processing plants remaining open will be able to maintain normal production levels and prevent shortages, which may not be the case given the disruptions caused by COVID-19 outbreaks.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, as experts have reported that there will be limited availability of certain meat products depending on the location, indicating potential shortages.
